abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was highly
            satisfactory. In-situ conservation areas for woody and
            non-woody target species were established, and institutional
            capacity for the development of a national strategy plan for
            in-situ conservation, was built. Despite successful
            achievements, project implementation was longer than
            expected, and, the one year extension of closing date, was
            due to biological and scientific reasons, which caused
            delays in the selection of gene management zones (GMZs). The
            lessons learned suggest that, a number of elements should be
            in place for successful in-situ conservation efforts,
            mainly, that forestry, agriculture, and environmental
            agencies actively coordinate these efforts, and
            specifically, that communities in the proximity of the GMZs,
            be properly familiarized, and participate in project
            management. Effective mechanisms, such as the Project
            Implementation Committee or Inter-Ministerial Steering
            Committee could cooperate, if limited experience exists
            among project agencies in working together; and, project
            design should include funding to secure community
            participation. Projects which are technical in nature,
            require adequate training in the most advanced techniques,
            same should be provided at the earliest stages. Finally,
            task teams' continuity is paramount to maintain mutual
            trust and understanding to attain success.
